content.description: Start matched on a small left facing rail low to the ground, work your way up the rail and top on this face.
content.location: A few feet to the right of the sawmill boulder.

content.description: Start with left hand on a small sidepull pinch coming out of the crack and right hand gaston out wide above the right foot which is on the starting hold for Dolly Parton. Right hand up to a thumb press on a flat chip before left hand to the large pinch coming out of the crack then right hand to the small lip. Left hand up to another pinch on the bulky overhand and high right heel onto the small lip and top out above the crack.
content.location: On the face between the crack and the tree to the left of Dolly Parton.

content.description: Same start as the stump but work your way left with good feet and some okay edges.
content.location: Far right of the sawmill boulder.

content.description: Climb Sawmill to the lip then traverse left into the top of Sawblades.
content.location: Climb the obvious blocky prow feature.

content.description: Stand start with a small sidepull for your right hand, a Gaston for your left hand and a high right toe move up and right with small feet and interesting hand holds. Fun move to the good lip out right, get a heel up and mantle the slopey lip to top out.
content.location: On the face to the left of the prow.

content.description: Start with a left and on a deep side pull and right hand on a rail. Grab a large pinch and stretch for the perfect sidepull crimp, top it out from there.
content.location: Just right of the blocky prow

climbs.name: Not So Laid Back(Split a Tip)

content.description: Sit start with one hand on the triangle shaped jug that is the start of the Laid back and the other on a crimp out left . With good feet go up to the crimps next to the good side pull. Side pull is off. Another tricky move to a crimp out right then throw to the lip. Top it out.
content.location: On the same side of the boulder as Dolly Parton. The route is under the big ledge that runs across the right half of the face. One of the start holds is a distinct triangle shaped jug under the middle of the ledge.

content.description: Same start as Laid back except once you hit the first side pull move your feet up and either match the sidepull or use an intermediate crimp to make the move to the ledge, mantle the ledge and top out directly over, do not work left or right.
content.location: In the middle of the right face of the boulder.

content.description: Same start as Elvis, then traverse left using the great side pulls on the face then top out same as Laid Back. Its all about the foot work.
content.location: Traverses the right face of the boulder from right to left

climbs.name: Laid Back
climbs.fa: FA by Carson Morris and was the first problem put up at the sawmill

content.description: Sit start with good feet and your hands on a fat jug, pop up for the first massive sidepull. Work your feet up and lay back the other massive sidepull to a mellow top out.
content.location: In the middle of the right face of the boulder.

content.description: Excellent stemming up the flared corner to the lip. Mantle left onto the top.
content.location: The obvious dihedral in the center of the wall.

climbs.name: Elvis
climbs.fa: FA by Brandon Spera, named Elvise because if you look at the climb from a few steps back it looks like Elvis or at least some think so.

content.description: Sit start with good feet, a right hand crimp on the arête and a high left hand sidepull, if you cant reach the side pull a bad crimp can be used below it, making the start a little harder. Work your way up using the larger sidepull and holds on the arête to a good top out.
content.location: All the way right on the right hand face of the boulder. Easy decent by hiking off the top.

content.description: Sit start with your right hand on a crimp and your left hand on a slopey sidepull. Compress up the left arete to achieve the  big move to slopey jug.
content.location: Left hand arête of right face.

content.description: Sit start on good holds follow the blocky holds up to a good lip, work your hands left and either pop a heel or a high toe and mantle up.
content.location: The obvious blocky prow of the boulder.

content.description: The Sawmill is a bouldering field that consists of one mini cliff band, with potential for further expansion in surrounding area. The rock is solid/strong granite in a secluded area that is slightly shady due to the tree coverage. Originally found by Joe Pearson while running through College Woods. He brought it to our attention that their was potential for climbing and with a bit of cleaning numerous routes were put up varying from V0-6. The Sawmill area gets its name from the slightly visible UNH Sawmill.
